@{557058:684383ab-ac95-4859-a350-4a6f41a94a22} and I were discussing this issue. We "think" this strategy might work with the `enable_ros_network` solution in parallel:

1. Replace the `<node name="spawn_model" ...` call in our launch files with another call to a custom node.
2. This custom node reads the `robot_description` value from the ROS parameter server.
3. Then, calls the external command `gz model -s <string>`, where <string> is the value read in step \(2\). Note that this step requires gz transport to work but it should because we're inside the simulation container.

@Shane Loretz and I were discussing this issue. We "think" this strategy might work with the enable_ros_network solution in parallel:

  1. Replace the <node name="spawn_model" ... call in our launch files with another call to a custom node.
  2. This custom node reads the robot_description value from the ROS parameter server.
  3. Then, calls the external command gz model -s <string>, where <string> is the value read in step (2). Note that this step requires gz transport to work but it should because we're inside the simulation container.
